with issues affecting the Homewood campus, as well as the
University as a whole.
Therefore, the success of the News-Letter depends on the
participation of the entire community in this venture. People
from all divisions of the University are invited to submit

The Newton H. White Athletic
Center will begin its full-time
schedule on Monday, September

by the entire Hopkins
community including guests at

weekend, provided they bring
their parents identification card.

may bring one or two guests with

Service cage or call extension 797
after 10 p.m. Tennis reservations
can be made 5 days in advance at
the Athletic Office or by calling
extension 791 between 12 noon
and 4 p.m.

inner gear are now available to
Hopkins students and faculty. In

the sports section of the

Fund Record
Officials of the Johns Hopkins
Fund reported over the summer
that this year's annual
fund-raising campaign was the
most successful ever, as alumni of
the University pledged
$2,009,000 to Hopkins in
response to the annual Rollcall.
This year's total was an
increase of only about $6,000

over last year. However, donor
participation was up substantially
this year with 17,147 alumni
contributing, as compared to
15,362 last year. Approximately
31 per cent of all people solicited
contributed, roughly a 12 per
cent increase in participation
over last year.
The School of Medicine
received the lion's share of the
donations, netting nearly
$610,000. The Division of Arts
and Sciences received $220,000
and the Evening College garnered
$12,148.
Robert Macgill, Vice President
or the Hopkins Fund, cited
"good class agents" as the main
reason for Hopkins' steadily
risin Rollcall totals. T hp

principal thrust behind the
large-scale solicitations are the
work of the alumni from the
various classes, Macgill said.
Last year's Rollcall total,

the two million dollar level had
been surpassed, was not enough
to keep assed was not enough to
keep Hopkins in the Council for
Financial Aid to Education's top

dropped to eleventh in the

The Rollcall has served for 27

for soliciting contributions.
Money collected from the
Hopkins Hundreds campaign,

the Rollcall donations.
Because the Hundreds

have not yet begun to feel the
squeeze of the two fund-raising

Money from the Rollcall goes

of the University, while the
Hundreds campaign monies go
towards increases in the
University endowment and
capital improvments.

Among numerous
administrative changes and
appointments, Glen A. Thomas,
formerly the Associate Director
of Admissigns here, was named
Admissions Director in early
July. Thomas replaced John
Riina, who left Admissions to
serve as manager of the new
audio-visual division of the Johns

Hopkins University Press.

appointment, Homewood Vice
President George Bentcn
commented,"We are fortunate in.
being able to fill this position
with a young man of Mr.
Thomas' demonstrated
administrative skill and
familiarity with Johns Hopkins."
Over 200 applications were
originally submitted for the
position, from which six final
candidates were selected. The
informal committee to choose
the new admissions chief
included Benton, newly
appointed Academic Services
head Larry Denton, the
Admissions staff acting as an ad
hoc group, and several students
serving as consultants.
Thomas has worked in the
Admissions Office for six years.
